news_1_excerpt: HCMC - A 10-year-old white Bengal tiger named Ngo Khong died on the night of July 7 after a period of multiple illnesses despite intensive treatment.
news_1_full:
HCMC - A 10-year-old white Bengal tiger named Ngo Khong died on the night of July 7 after a period of multiple illnesses despite intensive treatment.
Ngo Khong was one of two white Bengal tigers (the other being its younger sibling) born at the Saigon Zoo, becoming a rare symbol here.
Over 10 years, it attracted millions of visitors.
According to the management, the tiger had shown signs of illness for several months and was diligently treated by veterinarians, but did not survive due to complex medical conditions.
Ngo Khong's passing is a great loss for the Saigon Zoo and animal lovers. According to the Saigon Zoo, the genetic mutation in white Bengal tigers often comes with biological defects, which can be obvious or hidden.
Common issues include visual impairment, vision disorders, and a weak immune system..., reducing their survival ability in the wild as well as maintaining health in captivity.
The white tiger (also known as the Bengal tiger) is a rare species, mainly distributed in India, Myanmar, Bangladesh, and rarely seen in the wild, facing a high risk of extinction.
There are currently about 3,200 white tigers in the world, mostly kept in zoos.
news_2_excerpt: HCMC - Hundreds of visitors, mainly families with young children, attended a birthday party and farewell for a retiring Bengal tiger at the Saigon Zoo.
news_2_full:
On the morning of May 11, the Saigon Zoo held an exchange program titled 'Tigers don't just roar, Tigers also inspire,' to bid farewell to the male Bengal tiger, code 6170, affectionately known to visitors as 'Mr. Tay the tiger.'
Although not born at the zoo, Mr. Tay has long been a name associated with the respect of the animal care staff here.

Rescued and transferred from the Binh Duong Provincial Forest Protection Department, Mr. Tay came to the zoo in poor health and a emaciated state after living in a non-ideal environment.
However, after just a few weeks, thanks to a scientific care regimen and the dedication of the staff, Mr. Tay recovered, regaining his inherent majesty.
Since then, Tay has lived at the zoo as a 'quiet grandfather'—orderly, disciplined, and full of character.
Mr. Tay is now retiring at the age of 15. Zoo staff share that tigers mature earlier than humans and have shorter lifespans, so 15 years for a tiger is a very old age, similar to a human in their 70s or 80s.

In the afternoon, Mr. Tay's favorite spot is the cool water pool – where he often soaks quietly, gazing into the distance as if reflecting on days gone by. Mr. Tay is known for being 'difficult' with his neighbors but especially gentle with his two grand-cubs, Binh and Duong.
When lying quietly in front of the cubs' enclosure, Mr. Tay seems to be guarding their sleep, protecting the peace for the next generation.
Now that he has reached retirement age, Mr. Tay will leave the main tiger enclosure and move to a new, separate retirement area.
This is the Cu Chi Safari logistics area, spanning over 50 hectares, designed to be quiet and cool with a large playground and plenty of shade trees.
Many visitors came to send their farewells to Mr. Tay.
As if sensing the affection from everyone, he also gave a slight nod, like a meaningful goodbye after a long time at the Saigon Zoo.
news_3_excerpt: Saigon Zoo reported a 50% decrease in after-tax profit for the first quarter compared to the same period last year, down to 1.7 billion VND due to increased costs.
news_3_full:
Saigon Zoo earned nearly 2.2 billion VND in profit in the first 3 months of the year, a 50% decrease compared to the same period in 2024 but a significant improvement from the previous three quarters.
The Q1 financial report shows that Saigon Zoo Co., Ltd. had revenue of over 38.6 billion VND, an increase of over 9% compared to the same period last year.
In the first 3 months of the year, the zoo sold over 462,000 admission tickets, nearly 11% higher than the same period.
On average, more than 5,100 visitors entered the zoo daily.
Besides ticket sales, the company also had additional revenue from beverage - food services, games, car parking, and train - electric tram tickets...

However, the cost of goods sold increased faster than revenue.
After deductions, their gross profit was nearly 8.7 billion VND, a decrease of over 11%.
The company continued to have no financial or sales expenses.
They only incurred administrative expenses, which increased by nearly 16% to 6.6 billion VND.
In total, the Saigon Zoo's after-tax profit was nearly 2.2 billion VND.
This level is only half of the same period last year but has improved significantly compared to the last 3 quarters of 2024. They currently have over 12.3 billion VND in accumulated profit.
As of the end of March, the company's total assets reached over 846 billion VND, an increase of over 5% from the beginning of the year, mainly due to unfinished construction costs.
Liabilities were recorded at over 15 billion VND, a 28% decrease, mostly payables to employees.
Saigon Zoo Co., Ltd. is a 100% state-owned enterprise under the HCMC People's Committee, operating the facility of the same name in the center of District 1. Established in 1864 with the original name Botanical and Zoological Garden, it was later commonly called the Zoo.
The 160-year-old facility has become a conservation, breeding, and development center for fauna and flora.
Since 2015, the Saigon Zoo has been fully financially autonomous, with no budget support.
Late last year, the District 1 Tax Department issued a tax debt notice for Saigon Zoo as of October 31, amounting to over 846 billion VND based on a total leased land area of 158,117 m2.
However, company leaders affirmed they only use 5,590 m2, or just over 3.5% of the total area, for commercial services.
The remaining land is used for animal enclosures, park landscapes, and public services not for profit.
Subsequently, the HCMC People's Committee adjusted by allocating over 96% of the public-purpose land area for the Saigon Zoo to manage and use.
For the remaining land for business (parking, refreshment stalls, food courts, game areas, offices...), the enterprise will continue to lease it on an annual payment basis.
Based on this, the tax authorities were also assigned to recalculate the land rent for the company.
news_4_excerpt: After HCMC cleared its 850 billion VND land rent debt, Saigon Zoo Co., Ltd. reported a profit again in the first 9 months of the year, reaching 4.8 billion VND.
news_4_full:
Debt-free thanks to increased revenue
In the first 9 months of 2025, Saigon Zoo Co., Ltd. recorded nearly 122 billion VND in revenue, an increase of over 13% compared to the same period last year.
Financial reports show that the unit's business operations still largely depend on the number of direct visitors.
Admission tickets continue to be the 'backbone' of revenue, with over 1.5 million visitors bringing in nearly 78 billion VND, accounting for over 60% of the total revenue.
In addition, ancillary services such as beverage sales, dining, game areas, internal transport services, and souvenir sales also contributed significantly with over 20.5 billion VND during this period.
Although service revenue has increased, its proportion is still modest compared to ticket revenue, indicating that the zoo's commercial exploitation model still has much room for development.
After deducting the cost of goods sold, the gross profit reached nearly 35 billion VND.
The enterprise also recorded over 3.3 billion VND in financial income.
By not using financial leverage, the Saigon Zoo incurred no interest expenses, significantly reducing its cost burden.
However, administrative expenses increased by nearly 22% to 28.8 billion VND, putting pressure on net profit.
The final result was an after-tax profit of over 4.8 billion VND, an increase of nearly 12% compared to the same period.
This is considered a positive signal, especially as the zoo has just overcome a period of financial stress and faced many challenges in conserving and operating a natural-cultural heritage site hundreds of years old.
At the end of 2024, the unit faced the risk of enforcement due to tax debt of over 846 billion VND, of which 787 billion VND was overdue land rent.
Because it operates not-for-profit but had to pay over 163 billion VND in land rent annually, the Saigon Zoo was in a difficult position for many years.
In early 2025, the HCMC People's Committee adjusted from leasing to allocating over 96% of the zoo's land area.
This helped the Saigon Zoo escape the land rent debt burden of nearly 800 billion VND, opening up opportunities for financial recovery.
A 'Green Icon' is recovering
Saigon Zoo was established in 1864, is now 160 years old, and is ranked among the 8 oldest operating zoos in the world.
It is not only a familiar attraction for city residents but also plays an important role in urban ecosystem conservation.
According to statistics up to 2024, the Saigon Zoo is caring for over 2,000 animal individuals of 135 species, including many rare species listed in the red book such as the Star Pheasant, douc langur, yellow-cheeked gibbon, golden deer, Asian golden cat, and clouded leopard.
In addition, the flora here is also rich, with over 2,500 trees and more than 900 different plant species being conserved, creating a green lung in the midst of the bustling city.
